basis: The user explicitly commits to the steps (water, 2-minute pause, four breaths, hunger rating, 30-minute reminder, clinician-approved snack if needed) and endorses the pause/adjust signal. They acknowledge nervousness but emphasize a structured, predictable approach and intent to check in with clinicians, which strongly suggests they will execute the plan.
cognitive_dissonance: Internal conflict between fear/rigidity around eating due to anorexia and the urge to follow a simple, controllable routine. The user seeks reassurance and validation to reduce ambivalence, balancing anxiety with a desire for structure.
negative_thought_patterns: Beliefs of vulnerability to environmental influence; fear of losing control around meals; tendency toward self-doubt about ability to maintain regular eating; concerns about triggering situations.
emotional_triggers: Mealtime anxiety, triggering situations, environmental cues, influence of others; heat and discomfort may heighten distress
effective_reinforcement: Encouragement to check in with clinician
coaching_notes: Maintain and reinforce concrete, small-step plans; continue using the pause/adjust signal; provide quick coping strategies for mealtime anxiety (breathing, grounding, pre-meal rituals). Encourage ongoing clinician involvement and environmental adjustments to support adherence. Monitor for signs of rising distress and be ready to adapt plan fluidly.
